stateCorrectness.name: Fraud proofs are in development
stateCorrectness.description: Ultimately, OP stack chains will use interactive fraud proofs to enforce state correctness. This feature is currently in development and the system permits invalid state roots.

risks.text: an invalid state root is submitted to the system.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, deleteL2Outputs function

dataAvailability.name: Data is stored on Celestia
dataAvailability.description: Transactions roots are posted onchain and the full data is posted on Celestia.  Since the Blobstream bridge is not used, availability of the data is not verified against Celestia validators, meaning that the Sequencer can single-handedly publish unavailable roots.

risks.text: the sequencer posts an unavailable transaction root.
the data is not available on the external provider.

references.text: Introducing Blobstream: streaming modular DA to Ethereum

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, CHALLENGER address
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER address

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, depositTransaction function

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is finalized the funds become available for withdrawal on L1. The process of block finalization takes a challenge period of 7d to complete. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds. This transaction requires a merkle proof.

risks.text: the centralized validator goes down. Users cannot produce blocks themselves and exiting the system requires new block production.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, proveWithdrawalTransaction function
OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, finalizeWithdrawalTransaction function
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER check

exitMechanisms.name: Forced exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular exit they can submit their withdrawal requests directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request or halt all withdrawals, including forced withdrawals from L1 and regular withdrawals initiated on L2. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular exit.

references.text: Forced withdrawal from an OP Stack blockchain

otherConsiderations.name: EVM compatible smart contracts are supported
otherConsiderations.description: OP stack chains are pursuing the EVM Equivalence model. No changes to smart contracts are required regardless of the language they are written in, i.e. anything deployed on L1 can be deployed on L2.

permissions.name: Challenger
permissions.description: Challenger is an actor allowed to delete state roots proposed by a Proposer.

permissions.name: Guardian
permissions.description: Guardian is an actor allowed to pause deposits and withdrawals.

permissions.name: Proposer
permissions.description: Proposer is an actor allowed to post new state roots of current layer to the host chain.

permissions.name: Sequencer
permissions.description: Sequencer is an actor allowed to commit transactions from current layer to the host chain.

permissions.name: ConduitMultisig
permissions.description:
* This is a Gnosis Safe with 4 / 7 threshold. 
* Can act on behalf of ProxyAdmin.
* Can change configuration of AddressManager (acting via ProxyAdmin) - set and change address mappings.
* Can change configuration of SystemConfig - it can update the preconfer address, the batch submitter (Sequencer) address and the gas configuration of the system.
* Can upgrade implementation of SystemConfig, L2OutputOracle, OptimismPortal (acting via ProxyAdmin).
* Can upgrade implementation of L1StandardBridge (acting via ProxyAdmin) - upgrading bridge implementation allows to access all funds and change every system component.

permissions.name: PgnMultisig
permissions.description:
* This is a Gnosis Safe with 3 / 6 threshold. 
* Challenger, Guardian.

addresses.name: AddressManager
addresses.description: Legacy contract used to manage a mapping of string names to addresses. Modern OP stack uses a different standard proxy system instead, but this contract is still necessary for backwards compatibility with several older contracts.

addresses.name: SystemConfig
addresses.description: Contains configuration parameters such as the Sequencer address, gas limit on this chain and the unsafe block signer address.

addresses.name: L1CrossDomainMessenger
addresses.description: Sends messages from host chain to this chain, and relays messages back onto host chain. In the event that a message sent from host chain to this chain is rejected for exceeding this chain's epoch gas limit, it can be resubmitted via this contract's replay function.

addresses.name: L2OutputOracle
addresses.description: Contains a list of proposed state roots which Proposers assert to be a result of block execution. Currently only the PROPOSER address can submit new state roots.

addresses.name: OptimismPortal
addresses.description: The main entry point to deposit funds from host chain to this chain. It also allows to prove and finalize withdrawals.

addresses.name: ProxyAdmin
addresses.description:
* Can be used to configure AddressManager - set and change address mappings.
* Can be used to upgrade implementation of SystemConfig, L2OutputOracle, OptimismPortal.
* Can be used to upgrade implementation of L1StandardBridge - upgrading bridge implementation allows to access all funds and change every system component.

addresses.name: L1StandardBridge
addresses.description: The main entry point to deposit ERC20 tokens from host chain to this chain. This contract can store any token.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

display.description: Public Goods Network is an OP stack chain focused on funding public goods.

contract.description: Main entry point for users depositing ETH.
Main entry point for users depositing ERC20 token that do not require custom gateway.

layer.description: The data is posted to Celestia.

bridge.description: There is no bridge that can attest if the data has been made available.

stateValidation.description: Currently the system permits invalid state roots. More details in project overview.

dataAvailability.description: Proof construction and state derivation fully rely on data that is posted on Celestia. Sequencer tx roots are not checked against the Blobstream bridge data roots onchain, but L2 nodes can verify data availability by running a Celestia light client.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There is a 12h delay on this operation.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

destinationToken.description: ETH transferred via this bridge is used to pay for gas and other tokens transferred are considered canonical on the destination chain.

validatedBy.description: Smart contracts on Ethereum validate all bridge transfers.

stateDerivation.nodeSoftware: The rollup node is composed of two software components: [op-node](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/tree/develop/op-node), implementing consensus related logic, and [op-geth](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth), implementing execution logic. The configuration file can be found [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/blob/v0.1.1/superchain/configs/mainnet/pgn.yaml).
stateDerivation.compressionScheme: Data batches are compressed using the [zlib](https://github.com/madler/zlib) algorithm with best compression level.
stateDerivation.genesisState: The genesis file can be found [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/tree/main/superchain/extra/genesis/mainnet).
stateDerivation.dataFormat: The format specification of Sequencer's data batches can be found [here](https://blog.oplabs.co/reproduce-bedrock-migration/).
